titleStmt.title: Finite-Time Control of a Linear Motor Positioner Using Adaptive Recursive Terminal Sliding Mode

affiliation.orgName: AnHui Key Laboratory of Digit Design and Man-ufacture
School of Software and Electrical Engineering
School of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science
Postdoc Research Fellow in School of Mechanical En-gineering and Automation

analytic.title: Finite-Time Control of a Linear Motor Positioner Using Adaptive Recursive Terminal Sliding Mode

biblStruct.note: This article has been accepted for publication in a future issue of this journal, but has not been fully edited. Content may change prior to final publication. Citation information: DOI 10.1109/TIE.2019.2937062, IEEE Transactions on Industrial Electronics

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

div.p: Payload variations, friction, and external disturbances deteriorate the control performance of linear motor (LM) positioners. To provide high-speed and highprecision performance for the LM, an adaptive recursive terminal sliding mode (ARTSM) controller is proposed in this paper. For the controller, a fast nonsingular terminal sliding function and a recursive integral terminal sliding function are developed in a recursive structure such that the sliding surfaces are arrived successively and ultimately the tracking error can converge to zero in a finite time. Furthermore, by setting an appropriate initial value for the integral element of the ARTSM controller, the control system is enforced to start on the sliding surface at the initial time such that the reaching time is reduced. Stability analysis is presented to prove the finite-time convergence and zero tracking error of the closed-loop system under the proposed ARTSM controller. Experiment results also demonstrate the effectiveness of the controller in term of significantly reduced tracking errors and faster disturbance rejection in comparison with a recently reported fast nonsingular terminal sliding mode (FNTSM) controller for the LM positioner.

div.head: I. INTRODUCTION
div.p: L INEAR motors (LMs) are widely used in many high- speed and high-precision motion control systems such as computer numerical control (CNC) machine, 3D printer, dual-stage positioning stage, etc [1]. Since there exists no conventional mechanical transmission, problems such as gear backlash, structural resonance, and stiffness variation are eliminated in an LM-based direct drive positioning systems. However, the control performance of an LM positioner may be considerably affected by system uncertainties such as the nonlinear friction, parameter variations, external disturbances, and measurement noises. To achieve the desired control performance, researchers have made many efforts to design robust controllers such as variable structure controller [2], adaptive backstepping control [3], [4], learning control [5], [6], sliding mode control [7], µ-synthesis-based adaptive control [8], etc.

Owing to the properties of fast convergence rate and strong robustness, the sliding mode control (SMC) method is widely used in many applications such as magnetic machine [9], vehicle active safety [10], feed drive system [11], industrial manipulator [12], quad-rotor UAVs [13], etc. Nevertheless, one drawback of conventional SMC is that only asymptotic convergence of the controlled output is guaranteed, which is insufficient for some high-speed control systems. To overcome this problem, finite-time sliding mode control based on LMI technique is proposed in [14], the design of which is independent of the order of systems model. Alternatively, terminal sliding mode (TSM) control is proposed in [15], which can drive the controlled output to zero in a finite time based on a novel fractional-power sliding hyperplane, which is, however, associated with a singularity problem that results in boundless control input when the controlled output is within the neighborhood of the origin. In recent years, nonsingular terminal sliding mode (NTSM) control is introduced to avoid the singularity problem as reported in [16]. Similar to conventional SMC, the NTSM control has to compromise with chattering in the control input, which when used in mechatronic systems in practice, may damage the mechanical components and lead to control input saturation. To reduce the chattering, boundary layer technique [17], high-order sliding mode [18], adaptive SMC [19]- [21] and filter technique [22] have been investigated. For example, the second-order sliding mode control [23] is used for the control of robotic manipulators, in which the control input is obtained by integrating the discontinuous switching term and as a result the chattering is eliminated. However, only asymptotic convergence of the tracking error is obtained. Alternatively, the fast nonsingular terminal sliding mode (FNTSM) control [24] is developed, which contains no switching elements in the reaching control law. However, this method has to sacrifice the tracking precision. More specific, the tracking error can only converge to a region instead of zero [24].

In most sliding mode based controllers, the converging period consists of a reaching phase [25], during which the system is sensitive to system uncertainties and noises and the invariance of sliding mode control can not be guaranteed [26]. To eliminate the reaching phase and thus potentially reduce the overall convergence time, some approaches have been firstly discussed in variable structure control (VSC), but have not been fully investigated in SMC [27]. In [28], reaching phase elimination for discrete time-delay system is discussed. Motivated by integral SMC, a recursive reaching phase eliminated TSM control scheme for multi-input multioutput systems is proposed in [29]. However, the singularity problem still occurs in the controller which constrains its practical implementation. In [30], [31], a simple form of recursive TSM is used for ground and flight vehicles which requires less nonlinear operations.

Motivated by [24], [29], this paper proposes an adaptive recursive terminal sliding mode (ARTSM) control method for the LM positioner. First, a dynamic model of the LM positioner with parametric uncertainty is presented. Second, to construct the controller a recursive integral terminal sliding function is proposed which combines a fast nonsingular terminal sliding function in a recursive structure. In particular, an appropriate initial value is calculated for the integral element in the sliding function such that the reaching time is reduced. The main contributions of the proposed ARTSM control method are that it not only guarantees the finite time convergence but also reduces the reaching time by setting the initial value of its integral element. In addition, the tracking error can ideally converge to zero. These benefits overcome the constraints in the existing methods such as the conventional SMC, NTSM, and FNTSM. Lastly, those superior advantages are verified through the experiments on the real LM positioner and compared to the FNTSM controller.

This paper is organized as follows. Section II presents the structure of the LM positioner control system and the LM dynamic model. The ARTSM control design method is described in Section III, where the stability analysis and parameter selections are elaborated. Section IV presents the experiments on the LM positioner and provides the results and comparisons to verify the performance the proposed controller. Finally, conclusions and future work are given in Section V.

div.head: II. PLANT MODELING
div.p: The LM positioner system (by Baldor Electric Company) in our experimental setup is shown in Fig. 1. The positioning stage is directly driven by an LM with a travel range of 500 mm. The position of the stage is detected by an equipped position encoder (by Renishaw PLC) with a resolution of 1 µm. The voltage-to-current power amplifier is used to convert the control input signals into current commands to drive the LM. In our setup, the bandwidth of the power amplifier is 400 Hz, which is much higher than that of the LM dynamics. Thus, its model is simply regarded as a constant gain.

The plant model of the LM can be described by where m is the moving mass of the positioner including any payload, y is the position of the stage, u is the control input, f is the friction force and d lumps the system uncertainties including unmodeled dynamics, disturbance and measurement noise. The friction force f is affected by the moving speed of the stage. As shown in (2), k v is the viscous friction coefficient, k c is the viscous friction level and sgn(•) denotes the standard signum function.
div.formula: mÿ = u -f -d (1) f = k v ẏ + k c sgn( ẏ)(2)
div.p: In this paper, parameter uncertainties are assumed to satisfy

where m 0 , k v0 , and k c0 represent the nominal values, and ∆m, ∆k v , and ∆k c denote the corresponding uncertainties, respectively. The control objective is to design a robust controller to guarantee fast and accurate tracking performance of the positioner in the presence of system uncertainties. Define the tracking error e = y -y d (6) where y d is the reference command supposed to be twice differentiable. Combining ( 6) with (1), the error dynamics is given by
By subsitituting (3)-( 5) into (7), the error dynamics can be rewritten as

where f 0 = k v0 ẏ + k c0 sgn( ẏ) and δ = ∆mÿ + ∆k v ẏ + ∆k c sgn( ẏ) + d represents the reformatted uncertainty to the system (8), which is assumed to be bounded by [16] m -1 uncertain Coriolis forces generated by the rotational motion due to the clearance between carriage and rail on the linear motor. From now on, we will take ( 8) as the plant model for the control design.

div.head: III. CONTROL DESIGN
div.p: In this section, an ARTSM control design will be presented such that the LM positioner can track the reference command fast and accurately in the presence of model uncertainties and disturbances. To achieve this goal, a recursive integral terminal sliding function is introduced, based on which the reaching time is reduced and the finite-time convergence is achieved. Moreover, to compensate for the uncertainties, an adaptation element is employed in the controller to estimate the upper bounds of the uncertainties online. Finally, selections of the control parameters are discussed.

div.head: A. Construction of the ARTSM Controller
div.p: To construct the ARTSM controller, we first introduce the following fast nonsingular terminal sliding function σ given by σ
where k > 0, γ > 0, and α > 1 are the control parameters to be designed. The notation sig(x) a as first introduced in [32] is a simplified expression of

Note that for a > 0, ∀x ∈ R the function sig(x) a is smooth and monotonically increasing and always returns a real number [24]. In Appendix B, we can prove that when σ = 0 in (10), the tracking error e converges to zero in a finite time t σ bounded by (37).
Next, we propose a recursive integral terminal sliding function s as follows:
where σ is with (10), and σ I can be designed as
Here, the control parameters are with λ > 0, 0 < β < 1, and the variable σ is as defined in (10). In addition, to reduce the reaching time the initial value of the integral element σI is set as

Substituting ( 14) into (12), it is straightforward to verify that the sliding variable s(0) = 0. This implies that the control system is enforced to start on the sliding surface at the initial time such that the reaching time is reduced [29]. Since the initial states of the LM positioner are available in practice, σ I (0) can be calculated by
When s = 0 holds in (12), the sliding variable σ converges to zero in a finite time t s given by

The derivation of ( 16) is addressed in Appendix C. Remark 1: The sliding functions σ and s are associated with sliding surfaces of two layers, which are recursive. When the second-layer sliding surface is first arrived (i.e., s = 0), the finite-time converging condition of σ is met. After a finite time when σ = 0, the first-layer sliding surface is also arrived. Likely, the finite-time converging condition of e is then met leading to the tracking error e converging to zero in a finite time. In this sequence, each sliding surface is arrived successively [30].

Remark 2: It should be noted that the integral element in ( 13) is a continuous function and thus is chattering free. This property will be beneficial in our study because chattering reduction is of first priority for the LM control.

Finally, we shall give the form of the ARTSM controller based on the recursive integral terminal sliding function. By using ( 8), ( 10) and ( 12) and letting ṡ = 0, δ = 0 in (8), we can obtain the following equivalent control input
div.formula: u 0 = f 0 + m 0 ÿd -m 0 (k ė + γα |e| α-1 ė + λ σI ).(17)
div.p: Further, a reaching control input is introduced
div.formula: u 1 = -m 0 k 1 s + k 2 sig(s) µ + ( b0 + b1 |y| + b2 | ẏ| 2 ) sgn(s)(18)
div.p: where the control parameters k 1 , k 2 > 0, µ ∈ (0, 1); and b0 , b1 and b2 are updated by the following adaptive law
with η 0 , η 1 , η 2 > 0 to be designed and bi (0) ≥ 0 (i = 0, 1, 2). Hence, the overall control input of the ARTSM can be constructed as
with u 0 , u 1 given by ( 17) and ( 18), respectively.

div.head: B. Stability Analysis
div.p: The result for the proposed ARTSM controller is summarized in the following theorem and stability analysis is provided.
Lemma 1: Given the LM system in (1) and the control law (22), bi has an upper bound, i.e., there exists a positive number b i in ( 9) such that bi ≤ b i (i = 0, 1, 2) always holds.

Proof of Lemma 1 is in Appendix D. Theorem 1: Consider the LM system in (1) with the parameter uncertainties (3)-( 5). Then, under the ARTSM controller in (22), the tracking error e converges to zero in a finite time. Proof : First, the derivative of the sliding function s in (12) can be obtained as
div.formula: ṡ = ë + k ė + γα |e| α-1 ė + λ σI = m -1 0 (-f 0 -m 0 ÿd + u -δ) + k ė + γα |e| α-1 ė +λ σI = -k 1 s -k 2 sig(s) µ -( b0 + b1 |y| + b2 | ẏ| 2 ) sgn(s) -m -1 0 δ.(23)
div.p: Next, define the adaptive estimation error bi = bi -b i (i = 0, 1, 2) and choose the Lyapunov function V as
where µ i is a positive number. Using (23) and evaluating the derivative of V along the system trajectories with the proposed ARTSM control input yields
Since bi ≤ b i (i = 0, 1, 2) from Lemma 1, it yields
To make the expression compact, we define the following symbols as
Then, if σ s , σ 0 , σ 1 , σ 2 > 0, applying a little algebra manipulation on (25) yields
where
(28) It is obvious that σ s > 0, and for any η i (i = 0, 1, 2), there always exists a positive constant µ i (i = 0, 1, 2) such that

> 1, which imply χ > 0. Therefore, according to the result in Appendix A, the inequality (27) satisfies the finite time stability criterion. More specific, V will converge from any initial condition V (0) to zero in a finite time t r given by

This implies that the sliding variable s and the estimation error bi will converge to zero in a finite time as well. As shown in (14), by properly setting the initial value of the integral element σ I (0), s(0) = 0 is assured, which reduces the value of V (0) and thus the upper bound of t r is mainly determined by the estimation errors of bi (0). Furthermore, it has been verified that once s = 0, σ converges to zero in the finite time of (16). Therefore, under the proposed ARTSM controller, the tracking error e converges from any initial condition to zero in the finite time of t c = t r + t s + t σ .

This completes the proof. Remark 3: Unlike the conventional TSM or second-order SMC [16], [23], the proposed controller is featured with the integral element for improved tracking accuracy. Furthermore, the initial value of the integral element is configurable to obtain s(0) = 0 and thus to reduce the reaching time.

Remark 4: The developed fast nonsingular terminal sliding function (10) solves the singularity problem occurring in the previous work [29]. In addition, we can effectively adjust the convergence rate by using the term γ sig(e) α in (10) when the system output is far away from the origin or by using ke when the system output is around the origin.

Remark 5: Compared to the FNTSM [24], the proposed ARTSM can guarantee the tracking error to converge to zero in a finite time rather than a bounded region. This is owing to the use of the adaptation law for uncertainty and disturbance estimation.

Remark 6: In practice, the sliding variable s is often chattering around zero due to system uncertainties and measurement noises, which will result in conservatively large estimation of b i according to ( 19)- (21). To moderate this problem, a dead zone technique [33], [34] is suggested for the practical implementation of the adaptation law as follows:

where > 0 is a small threshold value selected as 0.03 in our case. It is clear that when s is within the threshold, b0 , b1 and b2 will not increase but retain the present values. One can easily verify that when |s| < , ( 27) still holds. Therefore, the finite-time stability property is still retained in practice.

div.head: C. Control Parameters Selection
div.p: During the implementation, the practitioner has to compromise the desired tracking performance with other factors such as control input saturation, control command smoothness, and measurement noises. In the following, we will discuss the controller parameters selection guideline for the proposed ARTSM controller and give their values for the LM positioner.

1) Selection of α, k, γ: The parameters α, k, γ affect the dynamics of the sliding function σ as shown in (10). A large value for those parameters can lead to faster convergence of e to zero but request an increased control input in (17). For the LM positioner under study, α = 2.5, k = 80 and γ = 2 are chosen.

2) Selection of λ, β: Similarly, a larger λ or smaller β increases the convergence rate of σ as well as the amplitude of the integral element as shown in (12), which leads to smaller steady-state tracking errors but at the cost of increased control input. Here, we choose λ = 80 and β = 0.7.

3) Selection of µ: The parameter µ in the reaching control law ( 18) is designed to improve the robustness. A smaller µ improves the robustness but tends to make the control signal chatter. In our case, µ = 0.65 provides a proper balance.

4) Selections of k 1 , k 2 : The positive gains k 1 and k 2 in the reaching control law (18) affect the level of robustness by compromising the control signal smoothness. We choose k 1 = k 2 = 20 in the implementation.

5) Selections of η 0 , η 1 , η 2 : Ideally, the adaptation gains η 0 , η 1 and η 2 in ( 19)-( 21) can be chosen sufficiently small to achieve a fast convergence to the estimated variables. However, it may cause overestimation and saturate the LM control input.
During the experiments, we find η 0 = 0.1, η 1 = η 2 = 0.2 are a good combination.

div.head: IV. EXPERIMENTAL RESULTS
div.p: In this section, experiments are carried out on the real LM positioner system to verify the proposed ARTSM controller. To demonstrate the improved performance of the proposed controller on the LM control, the recent FNTSM controller reported in [24] for the LM is used for comparison study.

The designed controllers were implemented on a real-time DSP system (dSPACE-DS1103) with the sampling time of 0.2 ms. It can be seen from ( 17) and ( 18) that the proposed controller relies on both the position and velocity information of the LM. In our setup, the position measurement is available. For a fair comparison, we adopt an identical velocity estimator 0278-0046 (c) 2019 IEEE. Personal use is permitted, but republication/redistribution requires IEEE permission. See http://www.ieee.org/publications_standards/publications/rights/index.html for more information. as reported in [24] to obtain the velocity information from the position measurement.

div.head: A. Swept Sinusoidal Tracking Control
div.p: A swept sinusoidal reference of an amplitude of 1000 µm is used to evaluate the tracking performance and robustness of the controller. The experiment duration is 4 s, during which frequency of the swept sinusoidal signal linearly varies with a frequency from 0.1 Hz to 2.0 Hz. Fig. 2 shows the responses of the position and tracking error of both controllers without extra payload applied. We can see that the ARTSM controller achieves a smaller tracking error bound (TEB), which is less than 17 µm, i.e., 1.7% of the referenced amplitude. Comparatively, the TEB of FNTSM controller is around 24 µm, which is much larger. In both controllers, the maximum tracking errors occur when the reference changes its moving direction. These errors are mainly caused by the insufficient velocity estimation due to the coarse position sensor. Another significant improvement of the proposed ARTSM controller is that its steady-state error bound (i.e., ±3 µm) is consistent with respect to the variations of reference frequency. Instead, the steady-state error bound under the FNTSM controller increases with respect to the increment of reference frequency. This verifies that the ARTSM controller has a wider bandwidth for reference tracking control than the FNTSM controller. Fig. 3 also shows the control input signals under both controllers, which reveal that they consume similar levels of control input in average, but the ARTSM controller contains a bit more chattering than the FNTSM controller. This is because the ARTSM controller consists of an adaptive reaching law that involves a sign function of the sliding variable as can be seen from (18). Despite the cause of chattering, the sign function is essential to guarantee the tracking error converging to zero, which is not achievable by the FNTSM. This chattering is still permissible for the LM in our case and worthy for the improved tracking performance.

The main uncertainty on the LM positioner is the payload variations. To further verify the robustness of the proposed controller against payload variations, an extra 3.5 kg payload is mounted on the LM stage. From Fig. 4, one can find that the tracking performance with payload is maintained under the ARTSM controller which is still better than that under the FNTSM controller. The control inputs as shown in Fig. 5 exhibit a reasonably increased amplitude and chattering of the control input signals due to the compensation for the payload uncertainty.

div.head: B. Swept Triangular Tracking Control
div.p: The experiments are repeated by replacing the reference with a swept triangular waveform, whose amplitude is of 1000 µm. As can be seen from Figs. 6 and7, the ARTSM controller in comparison the FNTSM controller achieves better performance under the condition of without payload or with payload. More specific, the steady-state error bound under the ARTSM is within ±3 µm while the FNTSM is within ±14 µm. This is also because the ARTSM contains the integral element which can effectively suppress the steady-state errors.

div.head: C. Fast Rejection of External Disturbance
div.p: To verify the fast convergence rate of the controller in response to an external disturbance, a shock disturbance with a duration of 20 ms is imposed on the LM stage. The position profiles under both controllers are shown in Fig. 8. We can see from Fig. 8 that the ARTSM controller takes a smaller settling time of 13 ms for the position to converge to 10 µm while the FNTSM consumes a longer time of 25 ms. This benefit coincides with the property of the integral element in the ARTSM which was designed with a proper initial value to reduce the reaching time leading to a reduced convergence time.

div.head: D. Performance Comparisons
div.p: foregoing experimental results are summarized and compared in Table I, where the root mean square (RMS e ) and the maximum (MAX e ) of the sampled tracking errors are defined as
div.formula: RMS e = N i=0 e 2 (i) N(33
div.p: where e(i) denotes the i-th sampled tracking error and N is the number of samples.

It is clear that compared to the FNTSM controller, the ARTSM controller achieves much smaller RMS e and MAX e in each case. Furthermore, the settling time under the proposed ARTSM controller is significantly decreased by 48% in rejection of the shock disturbance. Hence, the ARTSM controller is demonstrated to provide both stronger tracking robustness and faster disturbance rejection. Referring to [24], the ARTSM controller is also significantly superior to the commonly used NTSM and H ∞ controllers with respect to the performance metrics in Table I.

div.head: V. CONCLUSIONS AND FUTURE WORK
div.p: This paper developed an ARTSM controller for high-speed and high-precision motion control of an LM positioner. The proposed recursive sliding mode structure assures that the tracking error can not only converge to zero but also in a finite time, which overcomes the constraints of existing slide mode based controllers such as the FNTSM. Furthermore, an initial-value setting technique is employed for the integral element in the proposed ARTSM controller such that the reaching time of the convergence period is reduced and thus potentially leads to reduced settling time. Experimental results on the real LM positioner have also demonstrated that the proposed ARTSM controller can achieve superior advantages of improved tracking accuracy and faster disturbance rejection than the FNTSM controller.

The future work will include the development of recursive sliding mode combined with chattering-free adaptive reaching law; comparison study with other types of finite-time sliding mode control; and exploration of the LM under the proposed controller for high-precision machining processes.

div.head: APPENDIX D
div.p: Proof of Lemma 1: Supposing |s| = 0 and from the equations ( 19)- (21), it follows that bi (i = 0, 1, 2) is increasing and there exists a time instance t 1 such that b0 (t 1 ) + b1 (t

(40) Based on the equation ( 23), from t = t 1 the adaptation gain will be sufficiently large to make the sliding variable s decreasing. Then, bi (t) will continue to increase until s is driven to reach s = 0 in a finite time ∆t. After that, bi (t) will stay at the final value bi (t 1 + ∆t).

It is clear that bi (t 1 + ∆t) is finite due to its continuity property. That means that for all t, bi (t) has an upper bound. Therefore, there exists such a positive number b i in (9) satisfying bi ≤ b i .
This completes the proof of Lemma 1.
